title: Gravity Attenuates the Transcriptomic Response to Spaceflight in the Optic
abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Eye and optic nerve (retina + optic nerve) pathology is a known risk in space missions 
(e.g. Spaceflight Associated Neuro-Ocular Syndrome, SANS). PubMed+1 
●​ Microgravity (0 G) on ISS is hypothesized to drive transcriptomic (gene expression) 
changes in ocular tissues that contribute to oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, 
and lipid metabolic stress. PubMed+1 
●​ The authors used mice flown on the ISS under different gravity levels (0 G, 0.33 G, 0.67 
G, 1 G via centrifugation) and then harvested optic nerve and retina tissues for RNA 
sequencing (RNA-seq). PubMed+1 
●​ They observed that microgravity induced substantial differential gene expression in 
retina and optic nerve consistent with stress, but that artificial gravity attenuates 
(reduces) this transcriptomic response, in a dose-dependent manner (i.e. stronger 
mitigation at higher artificial gravity). PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ They propose that artificial gravity could be a viable countermeasure to protect ocular 
tissues from spaceflight-induced transcriptomic dysregulation. PubMed+1 
 
Results (key findings) 
From what’s available in the abstract and supplementary descriptions: 
●​ Under 0 G (microgravity), many genes in the optic nerve and retina were differentially 
expressed compared to ground controls. These DEGs (differentially expressed genes) 
match pathways involved in oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid 
metabolism. PubMed+2Faculty Experts - Loma Linda University+2 
●​ Application of artificial gravity (AG) onboard the ISS mitigated those transcriptomic 
changes. The mitigation was dose-dependent: higher artificial gravity (closer to 1 G) 
produced transcriptomic profiles more similar to ground control (i.e. fewer changes) than 
lower AG. PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ At 1 G artificial gravity, the transcriptome in the optic nerve / retina was close to that of 
the ground control, meaning many gene expression changes induced by 0 G were 
dampened or reversed. PubMed+1 
●​ The degree of attenuation suggests that even partial gravity (0.33 G or 0.67 G) has 
protective effects, though not as full as 1 G. Faculty Experts - Loma Linda University+1 

 
Conclusion / Take-Home Message 
●​ Artificial gravity, applied via centrifugation aboard the ISS, attenuates the 
transcriptomic response (i.e. the gene expression changes) to microgravity in the optic 
nerve and retina. PMC+2PubMed+2 
●​ The mitigation effect is dose-dependent — nearer to Earth gravity (1 G) gives stronger 
protection, though even partial gravity shows benefit. PubMed+2Faculty Experts - Loma 
Linda University+2 
●​ Therefore, artificial gravity is a promising countermeasure to reduce 
spaceflight-induced molecular stress in ocular tissues, potentially ameliorating risks of 
SANS and related damage. PubMed+1 
●​ The study supports the idea that microgravity is a strong driver of adverse molecular 
changes in ocular tissues, and that replicating gravity (even partially) can suppress those 
adverse changes. MDPI+3PubMed+3Faculty Experts - Loma Linda University+3

/ Aim (summary) 
●​ The study considers the interaction of immune challenges 
(vaccination/immunization) and the spaceflight environment: specifically, whether 
immunization aboard the International Space Station (ISS) heightens cardiac 
inflammation. PubMed+1 
●​ Mice were immunized with tetanus toxoid + CpG before and during flight; transcriptomic 
profiling of heart tissue (versus controls) was used to assess inflammatory responses. 
PubMed+1

●​ In flight-immunized mice (versus flight controls), many transcripts associated with 
pro-inflammatory signalingwere upregulated (e.g. NF-κB signaling, cytokines IFNγ, 
IL-17, IL-6). PubMed

or synergistic. PubMed+1

health could have unintended interactions with spaceflight stress, especially in sensitive 
organs (e.g. heart).

Abstract 
The study examines immune and blood cell outcomes after prolonged low dose/low dose-
rate radiation exposure combined with simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading), 
evaluating hematology, immune cell populations, and functional readouts.

title: Implications for Spacecraft Environments: Understanding microbial growth in spacecraft can
abstract:
The ISS rodent habitat has provided crucial insights into the impact of spaceflight on mammals, 
inducing symptoms characteristic of liver disease, insulin resistance, osteopenia, and myopathy. 
Although these physiological responses can involve the microbiome on Earth, host-microbiota 
interactions during spaceflight are still being elucidated. We explore murine gut microbiota and 
host gene expression in the colon and liver after 29 and 56 days of spaceflight using multiomics. 
Metagenomics revealed significant changes in 44 microbiome species, including relative 
reductions in bile acid and butyrate metabolizing bacteria like Extibacter muris and 
Dysosmobacter welbionis. Functional prediction indicates over-representation of fatty acid and 
bile acid metabolism, extracellular matrix interactions, and antibiotic resistance genes. Host 
gene expression described corresponding changes to bile acid and energy metabolism, and 
immune suppression. These changes imply that interactions at the host-gut microbiome 
interface contribute to spaceflight pathology and that these interactions might critically influence 
human health and long-duration spaceflight feasibility.
results:
Microbial Alterations: Significant changes in 44 microbiome species, including reductions in bile 
acid and butyrate metabolizing bacteria like Extibacter muris and Dysosmobacter welbionis. 
 
Functional Predictions: Over-representation of pathways related to fatty acid and bile acid 
metabolism, extracellular matrix interactions, and antibiotic resistance genes. 
 
Host Gene Expression: Corresponding changes in bile acid and energy metabolism, and 
immune suppression observed in the colon and liver.
conclusion:
Microbiome-Host Interactions: Spaceflight-induced alterations in gut microbiota and host gene 
expression contribute to observed physiological changes. 
 
Implications for Space Health: Understanding these interactions is crucial for assessing human 
health risks and developing countermeasures for long-duration spaceflight.

abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Microbiome-based therapies often lack precision: how to selectively boost beneficial 
resident microbes is challenging. This study proposes a metabolic modeling pipeline to 
design precision prebiotics that selectively promote growth of target beneficial 
microbes. PMC 
●​ They applied this in a minimal microbial community model of Caenorhabditis elegans 
(host) with a beneficial microbe Pseudomonas lurida and a persistent colonizer 
Ochrobactrum vermis. PMC+1 
●​ They predicted candidate prebiotic compounds (e.g. L-serine, L-threonine, D-mannitol, 
γ-aminobutyric acid) and experimentally tested them both in vitro and in vivo. PMC 
●​ Four predicted compounds were confirmed to specifically increase the abundance of the 
beneficial microbe P. lurida. PMC 
●​ The authors conclude that metabolic modeling is a powerful tool for rational microbiome 
engineering, enabling precision prebiotic interventions. PubMed+1

●​ The metabolic modeling framework identified a set of metabolites predicted to advantage 
the beneficial microbe relative to others in the minimal community. PMC+2bioRxiv+2 
●​ In culture, adding these predicted prebiotics indeed boosted P. lurida growth relative to 
controls. PMC 
●​ In C. elegans hosts colonized with both microbes, feeding with these compounds 
increased P. lurida abundance selectively, confirming in vivo effectiveness. PMC 
●​ The modeling approach enabled targeting of resident microbial composition rather than 
broad-spectrum modulation. PubMed+1

paper_id: Molecular Mechanism of Microgravity
filename: papers/pdf_papers/Molecular Mechanism of Microgravity.pdf
title: Molecular Mechanism of Microgravity-Induced Intestinal Dysbiosis and Its Impact on Host
abstract:
Spaceflight and microgravity conditions disrupt the gut microbiome, contributing to metabolic 
and immune dysregulation. This study investigates the effects of simulated microgravity on 
intestinal microbiota and host metabolism.
results:
Spaceflight decreased beneficial bacteria (Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium) and increased 
pathogenic species (Escherichia coli). 
 
Serum metabolomics revealed increased tryptophan and decreased histidine, indicating 
disruptions in amino acid metabolism. 
 
Pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-6 and TNF-α were elevated, suggesting systemic inflammation.
conclusion:
Microgravity causes gut microbiota imbalances, affecting metabolism and immune function. 
 
Interventions targeting gut microbiota may mitigate spaceflight-induced health risks.

title: Neutrophil to Lymphocyte ratio: A biomarker to monitor the immune status of
abstract:
This review/analysis assesses the neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) as a simple, 
systemic inflammation biomarker that could help monitor astronaut immune status during 
missions. It collates available spaceflight and clinical evidence supporting NLR 
responsiveness to stress, infection, and inflammation.
results:
Across studies, elevated NLR correlated with systemic inflammation and immune 
dysregulation associated with spaceflight or analog conditions. The authors highlight 
relationships of NLR with other inflammatory markers and discuss operational practicality.

NLR is a promising, readily obtainable biomarker for monitoring immune status in 
astronauts, but additional longitudinal and mission-specific validation is required before 
operational deployment.

abstract:

properties.

paper_id: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the Internation
filename: papers/pdf_papers/Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the Internation.pdf
title: Predicting how varying moisture conditions impact the microbiome of dust collected from the
abstract:
The commercialization of space travel will soon lead to many more people living and working in 
unique built environments similar to the International Space Station, which is a specialized 
closed environment that contains its own indoor microbiome. Unintended microbial growth can 
occur in these environments as in buildings on Earth from elevated moisture, such as from a 
temporary ventilation system failure. This growth can drive negative health outcomes and 
degrade building materials. We need a predictive approach for modeling microbial growth in 
these critical indoor spaces.
results:
Fungal Growth: Exposure to elevated relative humidity (RH) facilitated rapid fungal growth in 
dust collected from the International Space Station (ISS). At 100% RH for 2 weeks, fungal 
concentrations increased from 4.4 × 10⁶ to 2.1 × 10¹⁰ spore equivalents per milligram of dust. 
 
Diversity Metrics: Both alpha and beta diversity of fungal communities decreased significantly 
with increasing RH (alpha diversity: Q < 0.05; beta diversity: R² = 0.307, P = 0.001). 
 
Bacterial Communities: Bacterial communities also showed changes with increasing RH, though 
they could not be modeled using the time-of-wetness framework. Beta diversity decreased with 
increasing moisture starting at 85% RH (R² = 0.22, P = 0.001), and alpha diversity decreased at 
85% RH (Q < 0.05). 
 
Time-of-Wetness Modeling: The time-of-wetness framework successfully modeled fungal 
growth, with activation occurring at 85% RH and deactivation at 100% RH.
conclusion:
Predictive Modeling: Moisture conditions can be used to develop and predict changes in fungal 
growth and composition onboard human-occupied spacecraft.

title: Simulated Microgravity Promotes Horizontal Gene
abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a major mechanism of spreading antimicrobial 
resistance (AMR). This study investigates whether simulated microgravity (SMG) 
enhances HGT of AMR genes among bacteria withoutantibiotic pressure. PMC 
●​ They used bacterial genera (donor and recipient) and co-cultures under SMG vs control 
gravity conditions, tracking transfer of resistance plasmids and genes. PMC 
●​ The authors found that SMG increased HGT events of AMR genes, even in the absence 
of antibiotic selective pressure. PMC 
●​ They highlight that the space/microgravity environment may promote genetic exchange 
and adaptation among microbes, which has implications for astronaut health and 
microbial ecology. PMC 
Key Results 
●​ Under SMG, the frequency of HGT between donor and recipient bacterial genera was 
statistically higher compared to normal gravity conditions. PMC 
●​ This effect persisted even without antibiotic selection, indicating that microgravity itself is 
a driver of increased genetic exchange. PMC 
●​ The transferred genes included plasmid-borne antimicrobial resistance genes, 
demonstrating functional AMR gene movement. PMC

●​ Simulated microgravity promotes horizontal gene transfer of antibiotic resistance 
genes in bacteria, even absent antibiotic selective pressure. PMC

spread of resistance within microbial communities aboard spacecraft, potentially 
complicating infection risk and antibiotic efficacy. PMC

monitoring, antimicrobials) and perhaps suppression of gene transfer mechanisms in 
spacecraft environments.

title: Spaceflight increases sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca²⁺ leak
abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Microgravity exposure (in spaceflight) causes muscle atrophy and dysfunction, in part via 
dysregulation of Ca²⁺ handling in muscle fibers. The sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) pump 
SERCA (which pumps Ca²⁺ from cytosol into SR) is vulnerable to reactive 
oxygen/nitrogen species (RONS). Nature+1 
●​ The study aimed to test whether treating mice with the antioxidant MnTnBuOE-2-PyP 
(BuOE, a SOD mimic) could ameliorate SR Ca²⁺ leak, SERCA dysfunction, and muscle 
atrophy after spaceflight. Nature+1 
●​ They used soleus muscle samples from mice flown ~35 days on ISS, treated with either 
saline or BuOE, and measured muscle mass, SERCA activity, SR Ca²⁺ leak (via 
ionophore ratio), oxidative damage markers (4-HNE), and protein expression. Nature+1 
●​ Their findings: spaceflight caused significant soleus muscle atrophy, elevated SR Ca²⁺ 
leak, and increased oxidative damage; BuOE treatment failed to rescue those defects. 
Nature+1 
●​ The authors conclude that spaceflight-induced Ca²⁺ leak and muscle deterioration are 
not mitigated by BuOE, suggesting other therapeutics (targeting SERCA activation or 
leak reduction) are needed. Nature+2bioRxiv+2 
Key Results 
●​ The soleus:body mass ratio was significantly reduced in flight versus controls, and 
BuOE did not attenuate this muscle atrophy. Nature+2bioRxiv+2 
●​ Maximal SERCA ATPase activity was unchanged; however, the ionophore ratio (a 
measure of Ca²⁺ leak relative to pumping) was increased (i.e. more leak) in flight, with 
no rescue by BuOE. Nature+2bioRxiv+2 
●​ Oxidative damage marker 4-HNE was elevated by spaceflight and was not reduced by 
BuOE treatment. Nature+2bioRxiv+2 
●​ BuOE modestly increased SERCA’s Ca²⁺ affinity (pCa₅₀) across groups, but that did not 
suffice to offset increased leak or functional deficits. Nature+1 
Conclusion / Implication 
●​ Spaceflight increases SR Ca²⁺ leak in skeletal muscle (soleus), contributing to muscle 
dysfunction and atrophy, and this cannot be reversed by BuOE antioxidant treatment. 
Nature+1 

●​ Even though BuOE showed some effect on SERCA affinity, it was insufficient to 
counteract leak and oxidative damage in this model. Nature+1 
●​ The findings suggest that countermeasures solely based on antioxidant therapy may not 
suffice; more targeted interventions aimed at stabilizing SERCA function or reducing leak 
are needed to protect muscle Ca²⁺ homeostasis in space.

abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Spaceflight induces changes in brain gene expression (transcriptomic perturbations) 
across brain regions, some of which may relate to oxidative stress and metabolic 
dysregulation. PMC 
●​ The authors treated a subset of mice flown on the ISS with BuOE (a SOD mimic

involving metabolic, stress response, and oxidative stress pathways. PubMed+1

especially in oxidative stress–sensitive pathways. PubMed+1 
●​ The authors conclude that BuOE can partially attenuate the brain’s transcriptomic stress 
response to spaceflight. PMC+1

●​ Each of the four brain regions showed numerous DEGs when comparing flight 
(saline-treated) vs ground controls; both region-specific and overlapping gene sets were 
identified. PMC+1 
●​ Enriched pathways among DEGs included metabolism, oxidative stress responses, 
inflammation, and mitochondrial function. PubMed+1 
●​ BuOE-treated flown mice had fewer DEGs compared to untreated flown mice, indicating 
an attenuation of the transcriptomic perturbations induced by spaceflight. PubMed+1 
●​ The attenuation was particularly strong in genes linked with oxidative stress and 
metabolic regulation. PMC+1

●​ BuOE (antioxidant treatment) can partly blunt the transcriptomic impact of spaceflight on 
the brain, supporting oxidative stress as a mechanistic contributor to brain gene 
dysregulation in microgravity. PMC+1

paper_id: Transcriptomics Analysis Reveals Molecular Alterations Underpinning Spaceflight Dermatology
filename: papers/pdf_papers/Transcriptomics Analysis Reveals Molecular Alterations Underpinning Spaceflight Dermatology.pdf
title: Transcriptomics Analysis Reveals Molecular Alterations Underpinning Spaceflight Dermatology
abstract:
Spaceflight affects skin health, but molecular mechanisms are poorly understood. This study 
applies transcriptomics to skin tissue from mice and astronauts to identify molecular alterations 
and potential biomarkers.
results:
Significant gene expression changes in skin barrier function: increased filaggrin, decreased 
loricrin. 
 
Pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and TNF-α were elevated. 
 
Machine learning identified gene pairs predictive of spaceflight-induced skin alterations. 
 
Gene Expression Changes: Significant alterations were observed in genes related to skin 
barrier function, including increased expression of filaggrin and decreased expression of loricrin. 
 
Biochemical Profiles: Changes in biochemical markers, such as increased levels of pro-
inflammatory cytokines IL-1β and TNF-α, were noted. 
 
Machine Learning Insights: Machine learning models identified specific gene pairings 
associated with spaceflight-induced skin alterations, providing potential biomarkers for 
monitoring skin health.
conclusion:
Spaceflight induces molecular changes affecting skin barrier and inflammation. 
 
Identified biomarkers can aid in monitoring and developing countermeasures for dermatological 
health. 
 
Spaceflight induces molecular alterations in skin health, affecting barrier function and 
inflammatory responses.

/ Aims (summary) 
●​ This is a review that integrates research from radiobiology and biogerontology to explore 
strategies to enhance human radioresistance (resistance to ionizing radiation) for 
long-duration deep space missions. PMC 
●​ It surveys known radiation damage pathways and examines interventions, biological 
adaptations, and emerging technologies that might bolster radiation resilience in 
humans. PMC 
●​ The review aims to identify converging approaches from aging biology and radiation 
biology (e.g. stress response modulation, DNA repair, antioxidants, hormesis, genetic 
engineering) to propose a roadmap for future “radioresistance” enhancements. PMC 
Key Themes / Findings 
●​ Radioresistance is framed as a capacity to resist, repair, and mitigate molecular, cellular, 
and tissue damage from ionizing radiation. PMC 
●​ The authors review mechanisms such as enhanced DNA repair, antioxidant systems, 
stress response pathways, apoptosis modulation, senescence handling, and 
proteostasis, noting overlap with mechanisms implicated in aging and longevity. PMC+1 
●​ They discuss adaptive responses (low-dose radiation preconditioning), hormesis, and 
cross-resistance phenomena, along with examples from extremophiles and 
radioresistant organisms. PMC 
●​ Potential interventions include gene therapy, metabolic reprogramming, pharmaceutical 
modulators (e.g. radioprotectors), NAD⁺ boosters, senolytics, epigenetic modulators, and 
manipulation of repair pathways. PMC+1 
●​ The review also addresses risks, tradeoffs (e.g. cancer risk, off-target damage), ethical 
and feasibility challenges, and the need for experimental validation in relevant models. 
PMC

●​ Enhancing human radioresistance is an ambitious but potentially vital goal for enabling 
safe deep space travel. PMC 
●​ A multi-modal, integrative approach drawing from aging biology, radiation biology, and 
emerging biotechnology is necessary. PMC 

●​ The field is nascent: many candidate strategies remain speculative or untested, so 
experimental validation (animal models, human cell systems) is critical. PMC 
●​ The review argues for prioritized research in combining countermeasures (e.g. 
radioprotectors + gene editing + metabolic modulators) and for developing 
“radioresistance engineering” as a pillar of long-term human space exploration.

title: “Artificial gravity partially protects space-induced neurological
abstract:
(summary) 
●​ Spaceflight poses risks to the central nervous system (CNS), and understanding 
neurological responses is important for future missions. PubMed+1 
●​ The authors studied Drosophila melanogaster flies flown aboard the International Space 
Station (ISS) to compare effects of microgravity (SFμg) versus artificially simulated Earth 
gravity (SF1g) by inflight centrifugation as a countermeasure. PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ Inflight behavior under microgravity (SFμg) showed increased activity, but postflight the 
flies had significant defects in climbing performance. PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ Multi-omics (transcriptomics + proteomics) analysis revealed alterations in pathways 
related to metabolism, oxidative stress, and synaptic transmission in both SFμg and 
SF1g groups. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ However, immediate postflight neurological changes — including neuronal loss, changes 
in glial cell counts, oxidative damage, and apoptosis — were seen only in the 
microgravity (SFμg) condition. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ After return and acclimation to Earth conditions, both SF1g and SFμg brains showed 
progressive neuronal loss and glial phenotypes, with more severe effects in SFμg. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ The authors conclude that artificial gravity (i.e. SF1g via centrifugation) partially 
protects the CNS from the adverse effects of spaceflight. PubMed+2PMC+2 
 
Results (key findings) 
Below are several of the major findings: 
1.​ Behavioral changes 
○​ During the mission, flies in microgravity (SFμg) showed increased overall activity 
levels compared to controls. PubMed+2PMC+2 
○​ After return to Earth, SFμg flies displayed significant defects in climbing ability (a 
measure of neuromuscular/behavioral performance). PubMed+3PubMed+3Penn 
State+3 
2.​ Brain morphology and cell counts 
○​ The area of neuronal cortex and neuropil was reduced in SFμg flies compared to 
Earth controls and SF1g flies. PubMed+2Penn State+2 

○​ Dopaminergic neurons (DA neurons) were lost in SFμg condition; glial cell 
number changes were also observed. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ Markers of apoptosis and oxidative DNA damage were elevated in SFμg flies. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
3.​ Multi-omics signatures 
○​ Differentially expressed genes and proteins in both SFμg and SF1g flies 
implicated pathways of metabolism, oxidative stress, mitochondrial function, 
synaptic transmission, and stress responses. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ In particular, mitochondrial dynamics (fusion/fission), glycolysis, oxidative 
phosphorylation, fatty acid and amino acid metabolism were affected. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ Stress response and synaptic signaling pathways showed perturbations in both 
SFμg and SF1g, but more strongly in SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
4.​ Post-flight / acclimation effects 
○​ Over time (after return to Earth), both SF1g and SFμg flies’ brains showed 
progressive degeneration: further neuronal loss, glial changes, and more 
pronounced phenotypes in SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ SFμg flies showed greater glial loss and formation of glial aggregates (“rosettes”) 
during the recovery period. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
Overall, the result is that artificial gravity mitigated but did not entirely prevent neurological 
damage from microgravity. 
 
Conclusion / Concluding statements 
●​ The data support the idea that artificial gravity (by inflight centrifugation to simulate 
Earth’s gravity) partially protects the central nervous system (CNS) from the adverse 
neurological effects induced by microgravity. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ Microgravity (SFμg) induces more severe neuronal degeneration, oxidative stress, 
apoptosis, and glial dysfunction than the SF1g (artificial gravity) condition. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ However, the protection is incomplete: some neurological changes still occur under 
SF1g, and long-term deterioration continues after return, though less severe than in 
SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ The authors suggest that artificial gravity is a promising countermeasure to reduce CNS 
risks in spaceflight, but further work is needed to optimize it, especially for long-duration 
missions. Penn State+2PubMed+2

“Artificial gravity partially protects space-induced neurological 
deficits in Drosophila melanogaster” PMC+2PubMed+2 
 
Abstract (summary) 
●​ Spaceflight poses risks to the central nervous system (CNS), and understanding 
neurological responses is important for future missions. PubMed+1 
●​ The authors studied Drosophila melanogaster flies flown aboard the International Space 
Station (ISS) to compare effects of microgravity (SFμg) versus artificially simulated Earth 
gravity (SF1g) by inflight centrifugation as a countermeasure. PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ Inflight behavior under microgravity (SFμg) showed increased activity, but postflight the 
flies had significant defects in climbing performance. PubMed+2PMC+2 
●​ Multi-omics (transcriptomics + proteomics) analysis revealed alterations in pathways 
related to metabolism, oxidative stress, and synaptic transmission in both SFμg and 
SF1g groups. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ However, immediate postflight neurological changes — including neuronal loss, changes 
in glial cell counts, oxidative damage, and apoptosis — were seen only in the 
microgravity (SFμg) condition. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ After return and acclimation to Earth conditions, both SF1g and SFμg brains showed 
progressive neuronal loss and glial phenotypes, with more severe effects in SFμg. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ The authors conclude that artificial gravity (i.e. SF1g via centrifugation) partially 
protects the CNS from the adverse effects of spaceflight. PubMed+2PMC+2 
 
Results (key findings) 
Below are several of the major findings: 
1.​ Behavioral changes 
○​ During the mission, flies in microgravity (SFμg) showed increased overall activity 
levels compared to controls. PubMed+2PMC+2 
○​ After return to Earth, SFμg flies displayed significant defects in climbing ability (a 
measure of neuromuscular/behavioral performance). PubMed+3PubMed+3Penn 
State+3 
2.​ Brain morphology and cell counts 
○​ The area of neuronal cortex and neuropil was reduced in SFμg flies compared to 
Earth controls and SF1g flies. PubMed+2Penn State+2 

○​ Dopaminergic neurons (DA neurons) were lost in SFμg condition; glial cell 
number changes were also observed. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ Markers of apoptosis and oxidative DNA damage were elevated in SFμg flies. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
3.​ Multi-omics signatures 
○​ Differentially expressed genes and proteins in both SFμg and SF1g flies 
implicated pathways of metabolism, oxidative stress, mitochondrial function, 
synaptic transmission, and stress responses. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ In particular, mitochondrial dynamics (fusion/fission), glycolysis, oxidative 
phosphorylation, fatty acid and amino acid metabolism were affected. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ Stress response and synaptic signaling pathways showed perturbations in both 
SFμg and SF1g, but more strongly in SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
4.​ Post-flight / acclimation effects 
○​ Over time (after return to Earth), both SF1g and SFμg flies’ brains showed 
progressive degeneration: further neuronal loss, glial changes, and more 
pronounced phenotypes in SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
○​ SFμg flies showed greater glial loss and formation of glial aggregates (“rosettes”) 
during the recovery period. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
Overall, the result is that artificial gravity mitigated but did not entirely prevent neurological 
damage from microgravity. 
 
Conclusion / Concluding statements 
●​ The data support the idea that artificial gravity (by inflight centrifugation to simulate 
Earth’s gravity) partially protects the central nervous system (CNS) from the adverse 
neurological effects induced by microgravity. PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ Microgravity (SFμg) induces more severe neuronal degeneration, oxidative stress, 
apoptosis, and glial dysfunction than the SF1g (artificial gravity) condition. 
PubMed+2Penn State+2 
●​ However, the protection is incomplete: some neurological changes still occur under 
SF1g, and long-term deterioration continues after return, though less severe than in 
SFμg. PubMed+2Penn State+2

risks in spaceflight, but further work is needed to optimize it, especially for long-duration 
missions. Penn State+2PubMed+2
